awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Mechanism-guided enzyme engineering for fucosylated glycoconjugate synthesis
awd_abstract_narration:
Glycosynthases are enzymes that have been engineered to make instead of break chains of complex sugars (oligosaccharides and carbohydrates). With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Heather Mayes from the University of Michigan and Dr. Shishir Chundawat from Rutgers University to uncover how glycosynthases synthesize prebiotic oligosaccharides or carbohydrates. These enzymes fill a pressing need in research and industrial biotechnology for the ability to produce designer carbohydrates, sugars that are designed for a specific purpose. There remains, however, a lack mechanistic understanding for how to better engineer glycosynthases to be highly specific and efficient in making complex sugars. This project combines computational and experimental studies to provide a mechanistic understanding of how a glycosynthase (alpha-L-fucosidase) catalyzes creation of specific oligosaccharides, which will in turn enable rational design of enzymes to make designer carbohydrates. The broader impacts include designing efficient routes for creating human milk oligosaccharides that could be included in infant formula to bring the composition closer to that of human milk. Human milk oligosaccharides can improve human health by promoting growth of beneficial gut bacteria and lowering incidences of other pathogenic infections. The software developed in this work for designing such enzymes will be made publicly available. Finally, the studies form the basis for outreach activities that use the biochemistry of carbohydrates to engage with students from under-resourced communities in Michigan and New Jersey.

The overall goal of this project is to understand how alpha-L-fucosidases synthesize simple glycoconjugates (e.g., human milk oligosaccharides). The hypothesis to be tested is that a priori analysis of enzyme active and binding sites, based on sequence and structural data, can be used to predict mutations that will eliminate the hydrolysis activity of the enzyme in favor of glycosidic bond synthesis of bespoke oligosaccharides. The objectives of this project are to: 1) employ experimental and computational studies to identify key structural properties that determine whether a particular enzyme mutant will be an active glycosynthase; 2) create automated processes to predict and test which mutants of disparate enzymes will be active fucosynthases; and 3) predict and test mutations needed to alter substrate specificity. The results of this feasibility study will advance the path to production of a broad suite of oligosaccharides not currently readily available for research and/or commercial applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our goal was to engineer a class of enzymes called fucosynthases for the creation of difficult-to-synthesize carbohydrates for research and commercial biotechnological demands. In particular, we were focused on synthesis of complex carbohydrates (or sugars) called human milk oligosaccharides (or HMOs).  HMOs are valuable prebiotics necessary for healthy gut development but are challenging to produce using enzymes. Therefore, we focused on developing novel synthetic and chemical-biology based experimental toolkits, supported by computational modeling, to rapidly engineer improved enzymes needed to make HMOs containing fucose sugars. Our experimental toolkits helped us generate valuable training data to better understand how to mutate fucosynthase enzyme active site to create more efficient enzymes for HMO manufacturing. This work ultimately helped improve our mechanistic understanding of how fucosynthase enzymes work and provided a broader strategy for engineering enzymes for complex sugars synthesis.

To achieve our goal, we first created and validated two novel high-throughput screening techniques to rapidly screen fucosynthase mutants in the wet lab when using azido fucose as a donor sugar substrate for the very first time in reported scientific literature. This dramatically improved our ability to apply rational engineering and directed evolution methods to rapidly screen for improved fucosynthases that are capable of synthesizing bespoke sugars like HMOs. Importantly, this work also highlighted a mechanistic basis for why glycosynthase activity seen for azido labeled donor sugars shows a strong correlation with hydrolytic chemical rescue activity seen for mutant fucosynthases in presence of exogenously added sodium azide as nucleophile. Additionally, fucosynthase mutants identified in our screening pipeline were further characterized by the collaborating computational modeling team to understand why specific mutations within the enzyme active site improve fucosynthase activity. This combined computational-experimental approach can help bypass the need for both expensive experiments and complex simulations, and the results from this work are being tested at Rutgers University. 

This project also provided a unique opportunity for interdisciplinary training of several post-graduate (Postdoc), graduate (PhD) and undergraduate students, including several students from under-represented groups, in various aspects of hands-on training on diverse areas relevant to protein design, enzyme engineering, and glycosciences. Training and outreach enabled by this award has inspired several students trained via this project to pursue both industrial and academic careers. Additionally, we have submitted two patent applications for novel fucosynthase screening technologies developed in this project. Lastly, this project also supported development of an outreach activity at Rutgers that engaged high school students highlighting how innovative chemical-biology based tools can be used to solve fundamental healthcare related problems like biosynthesis of human milk oligosaccharides.
